[MY PREVIOUS ACTION - Turn 1]
Reasoning: Let me analyze the current game state:

1. I'm at Ante 1/8, Round 0 in the BLIND_SELECT phase
2. This is the very start of a run - I have no jokers, no consumables, only $4
3. I need to decide whether to play or skip the Small Blind

Current Blind (Small):
- Chips needed: 300
- Reward: $3
- Tag for skipping: Charm Tag (gives a free Mega Arcana Pack)

Upcoming Big Blind:
- Chips needed: 450
- Reward: $4
- Tag for skipping: Holographic Tag (next base edition shop Joker is free and becomes Holographic)

Boss Blind:
- Chips needed: 600
- Boss effect: All Spade cards are debuffed
- Reward: $5

Analysis:
- At the very start of the run with no jokers or consumables, 300 chips is very achievable with basic hands
- I have 4 hands and 3 discards to work with (standard starting amounts)
- I should be able to beat this Small Blind easily with just basic poker hands
- The Charm Tag would give me a free Mega Arcana Pack, but that's not as valuable as the money from beating the blind, especially since I need money to buy jokers in the shop
- The Holographic Tag for skipping the Big Blind is more interesting, but I should be able to beat the Big Blind too with 450 chips needed

Let me think about the optimal strategy:
- Playing and winning the Small Blind gives me $3, bringing me to $7 total
- This allows me to shop and potentially buy a joker or consumable
- With a joker or two, I should be able to handle the Big and Boss blinds of this Ante

If I skip:
- I get the Charm Tag (Mega Arcana Pack)
- But I don't get the $3 reward


- I'd still have only $4 going into the Big Blind, which means no shopping opportunity and less flexibility for future rounds

Skipping is only worthwhile if I can't beat the blind or the tag is crucial for my strategy. Since I can easily handle 300 chips with starting hands and I need the money to build my deck, I should play this round.
Command: play_round

3: Queen of Hearts (+10 chips)
4: 9 of Clubs (+9 chips)
5: 3 of Clubs (+3 chips)
6: 7 of Diamonds (+7 chips)
7: 6 of Diamonds (+6 chips)
8: 4 of Diamonds (+4 chips)

I need 300 chips total, and I have 4 hands and 4 discards remaining.

Let me look for possible hands:
- Pair of 3s: positions 2 and 5 (3 of Spades and 3 of Clubs)
- Pair of 4s: positions 1 and 8 (4 of Spades and 4 of Diamonds)
- No straights visible
- No flushes (need 5 cards of same suit)
- No higher value hands

Let me calculate potential scores:

Option 1: Play pair of 4s (positions 1 and 8)
- Base chips for Pair: 10
- Chips from 4 of Spades: +4
- Chips from 4 of Diamonds: +4
- Total chips: 10 + 4 + 4 = 18 chips
- Base mult for Pair: 2
- Total: 18 × 2 = 36 chips

Option 2: Play pair of 3s (positions 2 and 5)
- Base chips for Pair: 10
- Chips from 3 of Spades: +3
- Chips from 3 of Clubs: +3
- Total chips: 10 + 3 + 3 = 16 chips
- Base mult for Pair: 2


- Total: 16 × 2 = 32 chips

Both options fall far short of 300 chips. I need to discard strategically and draw into stronger hands. With 4 discards left, I have room to search for better combinations—ideally three of a kind, straights, or flushes. I'll hold onto the pairs as a baseline and discard the isolated low-value cards to improve my chances.

Reconsidering my approach: without jokers, I need solid poker hands to hit 300 chips. A high flush works—playing five cards from 10 to Ace gives roughly (35 + 50) × 4 = 340 chips. A straight could also work depending on the card values involved. - (30 + card chips) × 3
  - Low trips like trip 3s: (30 + 12) × 3 = 126 chips - insufficient
  - Even high trips like trip Kings: (30 + 30) × 3 = 180 chips - still falls short

I need to pivot toward building a flush or straight instead. Looking at my cards by suit: I have three diamonds (7, 6, 4) which gives me the strongest flush draw with 10 remaining diamonds in the deck. For straights, my options are limited since I'm holding mostly low cards and duplicates. I should discard the cards that don't support either of these hands - the spade pair and the Queen of hearts aren't helping me progress toward either goal.
Command: discard 1 2 3 4 5

I need 300 chips total, and I have:
- 4 hands left to play
- 3 discards remaining
- Current chips: 0

Let me identify possible hands:
- Pair of Queens: positions 4 and 5 (Queen of Clubs and Queen of Diamonds)
- Pair of 7s: positions 2 and 6 (7 of Hearts and 7 of Diamonds)
- Four diamonds: positions 5, 6, 7, 8 (Queen, 7, 6, 4 of Diamonds) - need one more for a flush
- No obvious straights

Let me calculate scores:

Option 1: Play pair of Queens (positions 4 and 5)
- Base chips for Pair: 10
- Chips from Queen of Clubs: +10
- Chips from Queen of Diamonds: +10
- Total chips: 10 + 10 + 10 = 30 chips
- Base mult for Pair: 2
- Total: 30 × 2 = 60 chips

Option 2: Play pair of 7s (positions 2 and 6)
- Base chips for Pair: 10
- Chips from 7 of Hearts: +7
- Chips from 7 of Diamonds: +7
- Total chips: 10 + 7 + 7 = 24 chips


- Base mult for Pair: 2
- Total: 24 × 2 = 48 chips

Option 3: Play two pair (Queens and 7s) - positions 2, 4, 5, 6
- Base chips for Two Pair: 20
- Chips from 7 of Hearts: +7
- Chips from Queen of Clubs: +10
- Chips from Queen of Diamonds: +10
- Chips from 7 of Diamonds: +7
- Total chips: 20 + 7 + 10 + 10 + 7 = 54 chips
- Base mult for Two Pair: 3
- Total: 54 × 3 = 162 chips

Two pair gives me 162 chips per hand, which is significantly better than either single pair. Over 4 remaining hands, that's 648 chips total—well above the 300 chip target.

I should also consider the diamond flush possibility. I have 4 diamonds (Queen, 7, 6, 4) and need just one more from the remaining 9 diamonds in the deck. A complete flush would score 35 base chips plus card values, multiplied by a higher multiplier, potentially yielding even stronger results than two pair. Even with an Ace or King of diamonds, I'd only reach around 292 chips—still falling short of 300. A flush alone won't get me there reliably. Playing the two pair now for 108 chips and using my remaining hands to accumulate another 200 seems like a more dependable approach than chasing the flush draw. I'll go with the two pair.

The hand consists of Queens and Sevens across hearts, clubs, and diamonds, positioned at cards 2, 4, 5, and 6.

The possible commands in Balatro are all composed of a single word specifying the action, followed by any necessary positional arguments, which are lists of integers.

The following commands are available in your current game state.
use_consumable <consumeable_position> <target_card_position1> <target_card_position2> ... <target_card_positionN> - Use a consumeable from the consumeables section. The first position argument is the position within your consumables inventory of the consumable you'd like to use. Subsequent position arguments specify the cards in hand that the consumeable will be used on, if that consumeable requires targets.
sell_consumable <consumeable_position> - Sell a consumeable from the consumeables section.
rearrange_jokers <joker1> <joker2> ... <jokerN> - Rearrange the list of currently owned jokers. Every index in the list of current jokers must be present, i.e. if there are 5 jokers, the indices 1-5 must be present.
sell_joker <joker_position> - Sell a joker from the jokers section.
play <card1> <card2> ... <card5> - Play the selected cards and draw new ones from the deck. You may play up to 5 cards at a time. If you play a hand, you must also respond with the intended hand type you think you are playing, and an estimate of the number of chips you think you will earn from the hand. Use the results of previous hands played to inform your estimate.
discard <card1> <card2> ... <card5> - Discard the selected cards and draw new ones from the deck. You may discard up to 5 cards at a time.
rearrange_hand <card1> <card2> ... <cardN> - Rearrange the hand of cards. Every index in the list of current cards must be present, i.e. if there are 5 cards, the indices 1-5 must be present.
